name: Original Medicare
description: You're 65, which makes you fully eligible for Medicare — a reliable, government-backed option.
This plan is a strong match if you're looking for stable, nationwide coverage.
While it doesn't cover everything, it's an excellent foundation you can supplement if needed.

name: UnitedHealthcare Community Plan
description: This is your current plan — it’s great for younger people with low income, but might not meet all your needs now.
As you approach retirement age, you might benefit from a plan that includes more senior-specific care options.
You may find Medicare provides better access to specialists and age-relevant benefits.

name: Kaiser Permanente Gold 1500/20
description: This plan gives you integrated care and consistent costs — ideal if you prefer a 'one-stop' system.
However, Kaiser’s network is limited in New York, so your provider options may be restricted.
Unless you’re committed to the Kaiser system, you might want to explore plans with broader access.

name: Cigna Open Access Plus (OAP)
description: You won’t need referrals with this plan — great if you like seeing specialists directly.
Still, with a $450/month premium and high deductible, it may not be the best fit for your budget.
This plan suits active professionals more than retirees like you.

name: Aetna Open Choice PPO
description: If flexibility and national access are important to you, this PPO gives you freedom to choose providers.
However, the $477/month premium and high deductible may not be the most cost-effective for your $30K income.
You’re likely to find better value elsewhere unless you have specific specialist needs.
